record.text: ok fresh thread for this: when i first read the nibelungenlied i thought 'wow this is kind of a slog' but now feel like it's a) the most rhizomatic text in the world and b) a sprawlingly complex ethical quandary in which even the righteous become violent as though violence is a slow-moving disaster
Do you have a preferred (English) translation? (Is there more than one?)
i simply read the penguin edition though i think the essays are bad
Why does Siegfried break Wotan's staff?

Because Wotan said that only he who doesn’t fear his spear can go through the magic fire. 
And because Siegfried must break all Wotan’s treaties?
bc wotan won't stop yapping
So it's a Western
...I need to read the Nibelungenlied again, I did not catch on to any of this when I read it at like 16
On the strength of this post alone,I feel good continuing to follow your thoughts. I love this book and this is a great take on it
Do you have any opinions on English translations? I see Penguin has editions of both the Nibelungenlied and Wagner’s Cycle, but these likely aren’t scholarly…

the penguin ring cycle isn’t very lyrical unfortunately (its extremely literal) and i think the Nibelungenlied is along that same spectrum. I haven’t read any other translations of the latter bc i don’t think there are many full ones. If you can get ahold of the Sabor ring box set it’s much better

there is this insane 500 page book called rules of the endgame that is basically about nibelungian space, objects, structures, ethics, etc and it will lowkey only make you more insane bc this is truly a rabbit hole people spend their whole lives going down

and so nibelungenlied adaptations from lang to wagner try to break or suffuse this complex ethical tension in various ways, usually to partially exonerate siegfried, but none of them can actually do it. it merely redistributes that tension to other places, events, characters within the same bind

bc the truth about the nibelungenlied is that everyone is a terrible person. and if they are not, if they are righteous, they soon become terrible because they have been touched by the Situation. that's why they all die. that's actually the greatest similarity it shares with the ring cycle

It's been a long long time since I read it but I remember being intrigued by Etzel and Dietrich von Bern: they're both heroes and villains of their own stories, but in the Nibelungenlied they're helpless observers who don't know what's going on but are inexorably drawn into the maelstrom anyway.
It’s enormously cynical and misanthropic.

& the thing about siegfried is he's simply the most fascinating linchpin in literature. a complete and total enigma. empty and elusive. why does he do anything? good, bad, anything, he just does it. less a man than a series of objects, he simply walks pleasantly into this dilemma that must kill him
For sure. I felt the same way about Aeneas. No internality to the guy at all.
I think it’s cause he’s dumb as a box of rocks.
www.amazon.ca/Nothing-that...

wagner solves this problem by making siegfried a fearless moron and lang solves it by making him beautiful and innocent but in the original text siegfried is not at all stupid. he's keen and uncanny. he moves from one scene to another. you can look in that well forever and not find an answer.
at risk of sounding kinda gamer brained, siegfried is sorta like a videogame charecter on a repeat playthrough looking for an alternate end. kinda nier: automata-ish.
he's like making decisions without really being more than an avatar for something, seeking an end to things without engaging with them the way other people do
Does he simply Enjoy Situations, one wonders
He is a Messy Bitch who Loves Drama
He and Loki/Loge, I guess 😄

it's somewhat important to note that in the other sagas (especially the thiedriksaga) siegfried is honestly kind of menacing! he's less like a beautiful little prince and more like a warrior or a mercenary, which really changes the sentiment of his demise. his luck simply runs out.

in the nibelungenlied, the courtly trappings of the burgundians etc do a lot to obscure violence in custom. much is displaced onto objects and rituals, which creates a rather fuguelike sensation of noble people following literary/social scripts while behaving not quite "ignobly" but anarchistically
anyway despite the language being rote it is the weirdest medieval epic of all time and it will unquestionably drive you insane if you let it

Thank you for this beautiful post! I’m only vaguely familiar with the story thanks to Wagner’s operas, but your comments have piqued my curiosity, and got me thinking about the same themes as they emerge in other epics I’ve read (viz The Odyssey) and even contemporary ones (Maguire’s Wicked).
Yes!! Always took him as an id-like figure. Unburdened by ego or fear (of death)
I believe this post was created with the help of…
just bc there’s one difficult word in there doesn’t mean it’s unclear
I’m sorry. I’m the old idiot who had no idea what you were saying. Your gen will certainly “dig it.”
The post isn’t about you. Hush there.

Didn't you smirkingly hand out worksheets with "reading strategies" when you were a "teacher"?
Use them.
